an4.12:4.1: “Mendicants, live by the ethical precepts and the code of conduct. Live restrained in the code of conduct, accomplished in appropriate behavior and means of collecting alms. Seeing danger in the slightest flaw, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.
an4.12:4.2: When you’ve done this, what more is there to do?
an4.12:5.1: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘keen and prudent, always energetic and determined’ when lying down awake.”
an4.12:6.1: Suppose a mendicant has got rid of desire and ill will while standing …
an4.12:8.1: lying down awake, and has given up dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt. Their energy is roused up and vigorous, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is unified in samādhi. Such a mendicant is said to be ‘keen and prudent, always energetic and determined’ when lying down awake.”
an4.12:9.3: a mendicant carefully bends their limbs,
an4.12:10.2: as far as the earth extends;
an4.12:10.3: they scrutinize the rise and fall
an4.12:10.4: of phenomena such as the aggregates.
an4.12:11.1: Training in what leads to serenity of heart,
